contentrichtext.text: {{about|the London suburb|the Belgian province|Hainaut (province)}} {{Infobox UK place | |official_name= Hainault |region= London |country= England |london_borough= Redbridge |constituency_westminster= [[Ilford North (UK Parliament constituency)|Ilford North]] |post_town= Ilford, Chigwell |postcode_area= IG |postcode_district= IG6, IG7 |dial_code= 020 |os_grid_reference= TQ445915 |latitude= 51.60373 |longitude= 0.08751 }} '''Hainault''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|h|eɪ|n|ɔː|t}} is an area in the [[London Borough of Redbridge]] in north east [[London]]. It is a suburban development located {{convert|12.2|mi|km|1}} north east of [[Charing Cross]]. The area is split between the Chigwell and Ilford [[post town]]s in the [[IG postcode area]].<ref>Royal Mail, ''Address Management Guide'', (2004)</ref> The area is part of the [[Metropolitan Green Belt]] and the suburb of Hainault is bordered on the east by [[Hainault Forest Country Park]], by open land to the north and the boundary with the [[Epping Forest (district)|Epping Forest]] district of Essex. ==History== ===Origins=== The name Hainault was recorded as 'Hyneholt' in 1239, and means 'monastic woodland'. This area was first recorded as a separate district in 1221. There is no connection with King [[Edward III of England|Edward III]]'s wife, [[Philippa of Hainault]], though the current spelling may have been influenced by way of [[folk etymology]]. The area was mainly forested, it was owned by [[Barking Abbey]] and formed part of the [[Royal Forest]] of Essex. The large density of forest meant the area was predominately used for the provision of [[timber]] for building [[ships]] and houses. A decline in demand for timber, and a greater demand for food, led in 1851 to an Act of Parliament authorising the deforestation of much of Hainault Forest. Within six weeks 3000 acres of woodland was cleared.<ref>http://www.hainaultforest.co.uk/3Forest%20of%20Essex.htm</ref> Hainault lay just inside the [[Ilford Urban District]] of [[Essex]],<ref>[http://www.npemap.org.uk/tiles/map.html#544,191,1 New Popular Edition Maps]</ref> almost straddling the border of [[Chigwell Urban District]].<ref name=vision_chigwell>Vision of Britain - [http://www.visionofbritain.org.uk/relationships.jsp?u_id=10199890&c_id=10001043 Chigwell UD]</ref> In 1965 Ilford Urban District along with an area of {{convert|81|acre|km2|1}} from Chigwell Urban District near Hainault were transferred to form the [[London Borough of Redbridge]] in [[Greater London]], along with other areas, namely [[Municipal Borough of Wanstead and Woodford|Wanstead and Woodford]], and that part of [[Dagenham Urban District]] extending to Hainault Forest. The population of the area transferred from Chigwell was 7,071 in 1961.<ref name=vision_chigwell/> ===Development=== Urban development began after August 1856, when the [[Great Eastern Railway]] built a line between [[Stratford station|Stratford]] and [[Loughton tube station|Loughton]]. In 1903, from the line at [[Woodford, London|Woodford]] Junction, a [[Fairlop Loop|loop line]] to [[Ilford railway station|Ilford]] was opened. [[Hainault tube station|Hainault]] was one of the stations on that line. Although it had been hoped that housing development would ensue from the building of the railway, it was a long time coming. Hainault station was closed from 1908, five years after opening; development began in the late 1920s, and the station was reopened in 1930. As a result of the [[London Passenger Transport Board]] [[New Works Programme]] 1935–40 (not completed until 1948 because of [[World War II]]) the line was taken over from the [[London and North Eastern Railway|LNER]] and converted for use by [[London Underground]] trains. By this time the suburb of Hainault was completed. ==Nearest places== *[[Chigwell]] *[[Collier Row]] *[[Barkingside]] *[[Chadwell Heath]] The nearest [[List of London Underground stations|London Underground stations]] are [[Hainault tube station|Hainault]] and [[Grange Hill tube station|Grange Hill]] on the [[Central Line]]. ==Sport== Hainault Athletic Football Club play in the Essex Independent Sunday League and have two teams of players. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.hainaultforest.co.uk Hainault Forest] {{LB Redbridge}} [[Category:Areas of London]] [[Category:Districts of Redbridge]] [[Category:Housing estates in London]]
